Bangladesh, Dec. 25 -- After a prolonged honeymoon for the digital economy, the dark side of the Internet, social media, and "Big Tech" has become increasingly apparent in recent years. Online, what is good for business is not necessarily good for individuals or societies. Big Tech platforms make it easy to manipulate opinion, spew hate, and incite violence.

We once naively believed that mass access to the World Wide Web would inevitably democratize information; today, we worry about the emergence of an "addiction economy" that is bad for everyone. What can be done to support more humane, ethical, and effective technology?

One important way to address this problem in a systemic way is by reforming education in the so-called STEM disciplines: science, technology, engineering, and math. Policymakers worldwide are already focusing on increasing the number of STEM graduates and the diversity of STEM students. But we should also expand the scope of STEM education, to ensure that students learn to evaluate and respond to the social, economic, and political consequences of their work.

This does not mean adding existing humanities or social sciences courses to a STEM curriculum. Rather, it will require the development of an entirely new curriculum that gives the next generation of technologists, engineers, scientists, and mathematicians the formal foundations - including shared vocabulary and intellectual frameworks - for considering the macro effects of their actions on society. Without such a framework, the gap between the promise of innovation and the reality of human experience will only grow.

Fortunately, the seeds of this educational revolution are already sprouting. Some universities are adding ethics classes to the STEM curriculum. Stanford University, with its deep links to the tech industry, has recently added courses with topics like "Ethics, Public Policy, and Technological Change" and "Computers, Ethics, and Public Policy."

Stanford has also recently launched a new Human-Centered AI Initiative, which recognises that "the development of AI should be paired with an ongoing study of its impact on human society, and guided accordingly." Last year, Cornell launched the Milstein Program in Technology and Humanity.

These early initiatives can serve as important testing grounds for new curricula and methods. But the real change will come only when all STEM programs provide students with the tools they need to carry out a credible assessment of their work's effects on humanity.

Of course, such changes will mean little if we do not know what the most effective tools actually are. That is why continued experimentation is also essential.

Casey Fiesler of the University of Colorado, Boulder, is pursuing just such experimentation by crowd-sourcing syllabi focused on tech ethics. The growing online database already contains more than 200 different syllabi from universities around the world. Yet only one-quarter of these courses are taught by computer science faculty. The rest are taught in departments such as law, philosophy, and communications, which means that they are not being tailored to STEM-related challenges. More fundamentally, such standalone courses are not ideal. A better approach, as Fiesler herself agrees, would focus on integrating ethics into "everyday practice" in the STEM fields. (Fiesler hopes that her database will help faculty make this case to their universities.)

This is the goal of the Responsible CS Challenge, launched last month by Omidyar Network, Schmidt Futures, Craig Newmark Philanthropies, and Mozilla. The two-year challenge should encourage computer science professors in the United States to integrate ethics into their undergraduate curriculum, so that STEM students can gain a deeper understanding of how technology affects humanity.

This is a good first step, but much more must be done. For one thing, while the initial focus on ethics makes sense, similar explorations will be needed in a wide variety of disciplines such as economics, psychology, and many more of the so-called humanities.

Expanding STEM education to include such broader considerations would serve as a cornerstone of a more comprehensive long-term strategy to ensure that technology serves society in overwhelmingly positive ways. That strategy must also include changes, say, to business models, incentives, innovation strategies, and regulatory regimes - changes that should be pursued by people whose education has prepared them to address the effects of their work on the rest of us.

Mitchell Baker is Co-Founder and Chair of the Mozilla Foundation and the Mozilla Corporation.

urn:contentItem:5XCM-Y1Y1-JBSN-30VR-00000-00HAI 2019 Fall Conference: Regulating Big Tech, with Marietje Schaake and Eric Schmidt2019-10-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:18ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1HAI 2019 Fall Conference: Regulating Big Tech, with Marietje Schaake and Eric Schmidt

In September, former Stanford math professor and ex-Google researcher Jack Poulson called on HAI to disinvite keynote speaker Eric Schmidt. In a letter co-signed by more than 40 former Google researchers, professors and tech activists, Poulson accused Schmidt of ethical misconduct during his time as CEO of Google.

HAI defended its decision to invite Schmidt, citing the conference's commitment to promoting diverse perspectives on the role of AI society. At the conference, Schmidt spoke alongside former European Parliament member Marietje Schaake, who has pushed for greater regulation of big data and stronger privacy protections.

Schmidt opened the session by describing how AI has enabled important breakthroughs in science research. As scientific disciplines become increasingly data-dependent, Schmidt said, powerful algorithms can accelerate computation and analysis process of the data and also lead to unexpected discoveries.

He added that current developments in health research facilitated by AI have made earlier diagnosis of serious diseases possible and "will save millions of people over the next five or ten years."

The achievement of powerful algorithms goes beyond medical lab or hospital, he said.

"Google, for example, automatically captions 1 billion YouTube videos in 10 different languages," Schmidt said. "You can imagine the impact of that to global diffusion of information."

Schmidt said that both the private and public sector must make sure these AI innovations are under ethical and legal control.

"We know that data has bias," Schmidt said. "That is not shocking."

He said that both the government and corporations should "understand the bias and identify" it to mitigate side effects.

Schmidt argued international collaboration between scientists and researchers was crucial.

"Even in a situation where everyone hates each other, there are still areas of common agreement," Schmidt continued, calling for cooperation with the talent pool of researchers in China. He added that the world could benefit from having a "common framework," through which governments and companies can establish norms in the discussion of regulatory structure and policies.

"I think it is also important that we establish right here right now, that the liberal values of Stanford University and Western values are the ones that should win," Schmidt said. "We shouldn't allow other values ... we need to be unified and clear on that."

Schaake spoke after Schmidt and focused her talk on the regulation of big tech. She argued that many contemporary problems "stem from over-, rather than under-regulation of technology." She expressed concern with the fact that "there's a lot of power in the hands of very few actors"

In contrast to Schmidt, Schaake questioned the role of technology in the life of the public, citing concerns about Chinese technological dominance.

"If AI benefits disproportionately from undemocratic and centrally governed models such as the one we see in China, but also other parts of the world, where data can be massively Hoovered up without much restriction and where human rights are not protected - and if AI in turn will make that undemocratic government more powerful - why do we have such high expectations of what this technology will bring us?" she asked.

"It's a little ironic, to put it mildly, that the same companies that are warning against the dominance of Chinese standards are in fact sending data to Beijing themselves," she said.

Schaake further argued for the early regulation of new technologies specifically artificial intelligence. "Perhaps the timing is never perfect, but I would prefer to be proactive."

urn:contentItem:5VND-85M1-JCMN-Y12G-00000-00Hair-Trigger Markets2019-03-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:18ZLexisNexisHair-Trigger MarketsZero Hedge

Mar 16, 2019( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1]. View original post here[2]. Authored by Adam Taggart via PeakProsperity.com,[3] Bull market liftoff? Or bear rally rollover? Stocks are at an inflection point. After a bruising end to 2018, the major indices caught fire at the turn of the New Year as the world's central banking cartel leapt into action.

Here's how the US Federal Reserve reacted: The central banks have more than demonstrated that they are now subservient to the markets. Losses will not be tolerated Which is why the chart below by Sven Henrich goes far in explaining why they've been in full panic mode this year: a major long-term technical breakdown threatened. As prices fell in later 2018, the S...00 broke through a trendline that had remained unviolated since the markets began recovering from the Great Financial Crisis in 2009: As Sven has been doing an excellent job of monitoring, this violated trendline may now have flipped from "support" to "ceiling" for the S... Which may be why we were treated to not just one, but three Federal Reserve chairs during last weekend's episode of60 Minutes. Their triple-strength "all is well" show of force was good enough to juice the S...ack up to the long-term trendline this week — but not convincingly through it. The market looks very much paused at the brink of a breakout here. The bulls are expecting a sharp rebound in GDP from Q1, which they claim was artificially low due the government shutdown. They point to 2018's solid 3% economic growth, claiming the US is humming along fine and about to get a shot of adrenaline once America and China announce an end to their trade war. In their eyes, the S...s poised to rocket higher once it punches vigorously above 2820. The bears see a topping out of a classic bear market rally, one that has been propelled by no convincing fundamentals — only central bank jawboning/easing and continued massive buyback programs (plus this week's rareQuad Witching[4]options expiration). They see an extremely overbought market, with stocks ready to break down to new lows for the year. Which Way From Here? If we look over at the bond markets, we see no confirmation at all of the recent exuberance in equities, especially the melt-up seen this week: When the bond and stock markets disagree, it's usually the (much larger) bond market that has it right. Moreover, many analysts, includingGoldman Sachs' volatility trader Moran Freeman[5], are predicting a near-term resurgence in the VIX, which would correlate with lower stock prices. Returning to Sven Henrich's charts, here he shows how we've been seeing a successive pairing of descending wedges for volatility (predictive of upside breakouts) and ascending wedges for the S...predictive of downward breakdowns). The tighter the wedges, the more compression they have to force prices to move quickly when they break: (Source[6]) This week, the VIX hit its lowest level ($12.50) of 2019. This suggests a reversal is much more likely going forward --possibly as high as $50[7]-- than continued suppression. And beyond the technical arguments, the fundamental underlying the markets are on their way from bad to worse. DoubleLine's Jeff Gundlach basically vomited on the bull case in his latest macro market outlook, optimistically-titledHighway To Hell[8](well worth the viewing). In it, he noted how global economic indicators are falling off a cliff at this point: And in terms of stocks specifically, he emphasizes that despite the early ramp-up this year, the S...was and is in a bear market", and that he predictsstocks will take out the December low during the course of 2019 and markets will roll over earlier than they did last year[9]. GMO's Jeremy Grantham sounds a similar warning, albeit a longer-looking one. Grantham, who has been expecting a meltdown in stocks since last year, not only sees the US stocks as overpriced — he predicts they will deliversub-par returns for the next two decades that will "break of lot of hearts"[10]among today's investors. Tech Looking Especially Vulnerable I wroteseveral reports last year[11]warning of dangerous overvaluation of the FAANG stocks, which had yet to show any weakness at that time. I went as far as to issue a rare notice that I was building a short position against these stocks, one rewarded with a 50% return when successfully exited three months later. If anything, the big Tech stocks look even more vulnerable now than they did back then. The NASDAQ (of which the FAANG stocks comprise the majority of the index's market cap) has rocketed up over 20% since its December lows, sitting now just 5% below it's all-time high. This surge in value is starkly contradicted by the negative developments arising for these companies in 2019. Here are just a few recent ones: Senator and presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren is proposing much tougher regulation, specificallycalling for the breakup[12]ofAmazon,GoogleandFacebook.She's also making the case thatAppleshould beprevented from selling apps[13]on the App Store it operates.Politicians and regulators in the EU[14]are making similar arguments. Two ofFacebook's key executives (it's Chief Product Officer and the head of WhatsApp)just resigned,[15]right as the companyfaces a criminal probe[16]into past security and privacy scandals. Apple'siPhone sales dropped worldwide[17]last year, falling 12% in the critical holiday FYQ4 quarter. Since then, smartphone demand in China has beenfalling off a cliff[18]-- at its lowest in years. Netflixis still burning cash at a horrifying pace while large competitors are readying to provide consumers with compelling alternatives. Disney recently announced its streaming service will include itsentire movie catalog[19](soon to include Fox's, as well), for a cheaper price than Netflix. Apple is expected to launch its service in May, and be free. GoogleandFacebookare under threat ofmulti-billion dollar fines in the UK[20]if they fail to rid their platforms of "toxic content". Google is also fending off similar fines inChina[21],India[22]andFrance[23]. I could easily go on. But do the above headwinds (along with a Q1 2019 US economy growing ata pitiful 0.4%[24]) justify Tech stock prices kissing their all-time highs? No. Not even close. Which is why I'm moving a percentage of my "dry powder" cash savings into a new short position at this time, one larger than I placed last year. It's not a move I take lightly (and as usual, this is NOT personal financial advice). I'm only doing it because, in my estimation, the preponderance of evidence for a near-term reversal is overwhelming my strong default risk-averse preference to sit on the sidelines. InPart 2: Assume The Crash Position[25]we detail out the wide range of options that investors skeptical of current market valuations can consider — for both protecting against a downturn and, for the more courageous, profiting from one. We also reveal the latest outlook from our endorsed financial advisor as well as the latest trades I'm making in my own portfolio. We should know soon which way this market breaks. If it indeed breaks downward, make sure you've prepared in advance for it. Click here to read Part 2[26]of this report(free executive summary,enrollment[27]required for full access). urn:contentItem:5YX2-0381-F08D-509Y-00000-00Half of all Facebook moderators may develop mental health issues2020-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:18ZLexisNexisHalf of all Facebook moderators may develop mental health issues

Photo by Michele Doying / The Verge In November 2018 I received a message that changed my life. A person working as a moderator for Facebook in Phoenix through a company called Cognizant asked to get on the phone and talk about some of what he was seeing there. His experiences shocked me, and after ... Continue reading Half of all Facebook moderators may develop mental health issues

Photo by Michele Doying / The Verge

In November 2018 I received a message that changed my life. A person working as a moderator for Facebook in Phoenix through a company called Cognizant asked to get on the phone and talk about some of what he was seeing there. His experiences shocked me, and after I wrote about what he and his colleagues were going through in The Verge, they would go on to shock a lot more people.

It was an office where moderators would have panic attacks while still in training, traumatized by daily exposure to gore and other disturbing posts. Where ever-shifting content policies, and demands for near-perfect accuracy, could make the job itself impossible. And where months of sifting through conspiracy theories led some moderators to embrace fringe viewpoints, walking through the building insisting that the earth is flat.

I wrote about the experiences of a dozen current and former moderators at the Phoenix site last February. A few months later, after hearing from employees that conditions at Cognizant s Tampa site were even more grim, I traveled there and talked to a dozen more workers. There I learned of a stressed-out moderator who died of a heart attack at his desk at the age of 42. I learned of multiple sexual harassment suits that had been filed against various workers at the site. And I met three brave former moderators who violated their non-disclosure agreements to describe their working conditions on camera.

By then a lawsuit by a former moderator named Selena Scola, which accused Facebook of creating an unsafe workplace that had caused her mental health problems, was working its way through the courts. And on Friday, lawyers filed a preliminary settlement in the case. I wrote about it today at The Verge:

In a landmark acknowledgment of the toll that content moderation takes on its workforce, Facebook has agreed to pay $52 million to current and former moderators to compensate them for mental health issues developed on the job. In a preliminary settlement filed on Friday in San Mateo Superior Court, the social network agreed to pay damages to American moderators and provide more counseling to them while they work.

Each moderator will receive a minimum of $1,000 and will be eligible for additional compensation if they are diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder or related conditions. The settlement covers 11,250 moderators, and lawyers in the case believe that as many as half of them may be eligible for extra pay related to mental health issues associated with their time working for Facebook, including depression and addiction.

We are so pleased that Facebook worked with us to create an unprecedented program to help people performing work that was unimaginable even a few years ago, said Steve Williams, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, in a statement. The harm that can be suffered from this work is real and severe.

After a year of reporting on the lives of these moderators I also profiled people who do the work for Google and YouTube it seemed clear to me that some percentage of people who work as moderators will suffer long-term mental health consequences. But what is that percentage?

Last year I published some leaked audio from a Facebook all-hands meeting in which CEO Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged this range of experiences. Within a population of 30,000 people, there s going to be a distribution of experiences that people have, Zuckerberg said, referring to the number of people Facebook has working on trust and safety issues around the world. We want to do everything we can to make sure that even the people who are having the worst experiences, that we re making sure that we support them as well as possible.

One of the most interesting aspects of today s news is that it begins to answer the question of how many moderators are affected. Designing a settlement required that lawyers for Facebook and the plaintiffs estimate how many people would make claims. And the number is much higher than I had imagined.

This lawsuit covers only people who have worked for Facebook through third-party vendors in the United States from 2015 until today, a group whose size is estimated to be 11,250 people. (A similar lawsuit is still pending in Irelandcovering European workers.) Both Facebook and plaintiffs lawyers consulted with experts in post-traumatic stress and vicarious trauma. Based on those discussions, a lawyer for the plaintiffs told me, as many as half of the members of the class are expected to qualify for additional payments.

In other words, if you become a moderator for Facebook, a legal precedent suggests you have a one in two chance of suffering negative mental health consequences for doing the work.

Perhaps those odds will come down as Facebook implements some of the other changes they agreed to in the settlement, such as providing more counseling and offering workers tools to adjust the content that they re viewing turning it black and white, turning off audio by default, and so on. But the risk to human lives is real, and it s not going away.

Another aspect to consider: how much will the average moderator get paid as a result of the settlement? The $52 million figure is less impressive when you consider that fully 32.7 percent of it has been earmarked for the lawyers in the case, leaving $35 million left over for everyone else.

The settlement was designed to compensate moderators in tiers. The first tier grants $1,000 to everyone, in the hopes that moderators use the money to get a mental health checkup from a doctor. For those who are either newly diagnosed or already have diagnoses, the settlement provides an additional $1,500 to $6,000 based on the severity of their cases. And then moderators can also submit evidence of distress suffered as a result of their work to win up to $50,000 per person in damages.

The sums could all be much smaller depending on how many members of the class apply and are found eligible for benefits beyond the first $1,000. If half the class were found eligible for additional mental health benefits and received equal compensation which will not be the case but may be useful for ballpark-estimation purposes there would be $4,222.22 available per moderator.

In my Twitter replies, lots of folks objected to the size of the payment, arguing it should have been much higher. Here, for example, is person who called the settlement a day s worth of random market fluctuation in profits for Facebook. I won t argue here many of these content moderation roles are essentially first responder jobs, not nearly as different as you might think from police officers and paramedics, and they deserve compensation and benefits more closely in line with the service they provide and the risks that they take.

I called up Shawn Speagle, a former Facebook moderator who worked at the Tampa site, to tell me what he thought. Speagle, who was not involved in the lawsuit, worked for Cognizant from March to October 2018. During that time, he was exposed to videos of extreme violence and animal abuse on a near-daily basis, and he began to overeat and experience night terrors. After being fired, he was diagnosed with PTSD.

He said that a year of psychiatric care had helped him significantly with his symptoms, but also that the things he had seen continue to haunt him. It s been a very long ride, Speagle told me Tuesday. It s been very difficult to forget about a lot of that stuff. You never do it just sticks with you forever. Even though it was just seen over a screen, those lives are never coming back. I just wish that Facebook would recognize that.

Speagle said that he sometimes felt embarrassed describing his PTSD to others, worrying they wouldn t quite believe a person could develop the condition by reviewing Facebook posts. There were a lot of times when it was humiliating, he said. But psychiatrists helped him to understand that the phenomenon known as vicarious trauma watching others experience pain is real, and can be dangerous. He has since become a public school teacher.

I asked him what he thought of the payout he might now be eligible for.

I would be fine getting no money, Speagle told me. I just wanted to bring this forward. When I did the job at Facebook, I was told I was making the world a better place for animals and young people. The reason I came forward was to stick to true to that. Money and a lawsuit have nothing to do with what I did.

Governing

Facebookis working to launch a new political advocacy group that would combat regulators trying to rein in the tech industry. The move escalates Silicon Valley s battle with Washington at time when government officials are still threatening to break up large companies. Tony Romm at The Washington Post has the story:

The organization is called American Edge, and it aims through a barrage of advertising and other political spending to convince policymakers that Silicon Valley is essential to the U.S. economy and the future of free speech, according to three people familiar with the matter as well as documents reviewed by The Washington Post. The people spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe the group because it hasn t officially been announced.

In December, American Edge formed as a nonprofit organization, and last month, it registered an accompanying foundation, according to incorporation documents filed in Virginia. The setup essentially allows it to navigate a thicket of tax laws in such a way that it can raise money, and blitz the airwaves with ads, without the obligation of disclosing all of its donors. Many powerful political actors including the National Rifle Association similarly operate with the aid of social welfare groups.

Facebookreleased a new report detailing how it uses a combination of artificial intelligence and human fact-checkers to enforce its community standards. The company is relying more heavily on AI for its moderation efforts. But some pieces of content, like memes and videos, can be difficult for AI to parse. (Nick Statt / The Verge)

Anti-lockdown protests in Australia were fueled by a conspiracy theoryFacebookgroup. The members have suggested, falsely, that Bill Gates is behind the coronavirus pandemic, and chanted arrest Bill Gates at a recent rally. (Cameron Wilson / BuzzFeed)

Misinformation researcher Renée DiResta says she wishes tech companies would expand their definition of who counts as an authoritative source. In this Q&A she discusses how platforms are managing coronavirus misinformation and where they could be doing more. (Berkman Klein Center)

Coronavirus infection rates are spiking in heartland communities, according to an unreleased White House report. The news is at odds withPresident Trump sdeclaration earlier this week that all throughout the country, the numbers are coming down rapidly. (Jonathan Allen, Phil McCausland and Cyrus Farivar / NBC)

Three days after a top White House aide tested positive for COVID-19, government officials working in the West Wing are being instructed to wear masks. The rule does not apply to President Trump, however. (Ashley Parker, Josh Dawsey and Philip Rucker / The Washington Post)

Here s what it s like being a contact tracer in the United States. These people are tasked with tracking down those who might have been infected with COVID-19. (James Temple and Bobbie Johnson / MIT Technology Review)

Nearly 40 percent of Icelanders are using a contact tracing app, the highest number of any country. Despite the widespread use, experts say the impact of the app has been small compared with manual tracing techniques like phone calls. As we told you it would be a month ago.(Bobbie Johnson / MIT Technology Review)

The Federal Trade Commission indicated that it s looking into privacy complaints related toZoom. Lawmakers have been expressing concerns about how Zoom collects and stores user data. (Reuters)

How big would a hologram ofJoe Bidenhave to be for every person in the continental US to see him? Roughly 1,400 miles tall, or 255 Mount Everests stacked on top of each other. If you re not clear on why this is currently a subject of debate, you may want to remain uninvolved. (Makena Kelly / The Verge)

Industry

Jack DorseytoldTwitteremployees they ll be allowed to work from home forever, even after the coronavirus pandemic has passed. Some jobs that require physical presence, such as maintaining servers, will still require employees to come in. This is a good thing, but also a few years from now Twitter is definitely going to realize that it has several hundred employees on the payroll who have not worked for the company in ages. Here s Alex Kantrowitz at BuzzFeed:

Twitter encouraged its employees to start working from home in early March as the coronavirus began to spread across the US. Several other tech companiesdid the same, including Microsoft, Google, and Amazon.

That month, Twitter human resources head Jennifer Christie told BuzzFeed News the company would never probably be the same in the structure of its work. People who were reticent to work remotely will find that they really thrive that way, Christie said. Managers who didn t think they could manage teams that were remote will have a different perspective. I do think we won t go back.

Twitteradded formerGoogleAI chief Fei-Fei Li to its board of directors. Li left Google after coming under fire for her role in the company s military contracts, which sparked employee protests and eventually led the company to abandon the project. (Tyler Sonnemaker / Business Insider)

Facebookshut downInstagramLite, its app aimed at emerging markets. The company which has always characterized the app as a test is planning to take what it has learned over these past years to develop a new version of the app. (Sarah Perez / TechCrunch)

Facebook Newspublishersare worried that the project might have slid out of the company s top priorities due to the coronavirus pandemic. The COVID-19 Information Center in particular seems to have been rolled out to solve precisely the type of problem the News tab was originally intended to solve. (Max Willens / Digiday)

The coronavirus pandemic and subsequent shutdowns have brought back bartering as people trade goods inFacebookgroups. (Rachel Lerman / The Washington Post)

In an interview that was immediately read and shared by every working journalist,Quibico-founder Jeffrey Katzenberg blamed the streaming app s rough start on the coronavirus pandemic. I attribute everything that has gone wrong to coronavirus, he said. Everything. Same, Jeff, same. (Nicole Sperling / The New York Times)

Hackers are impersonatingZoom,MicrosoftTeams, andGoogleMeet for phishing scams. As significantly more people are using the tools during the COVID-19 pandemic, the domains could be used to trick people into downloading malware. (Jay Peters / The Verge)

Ordering food from local businesses is a nice way to support the restaurant industry in your area. But it s a bit more complicated than you might think. OneGrubhubuser tried to order pizza from a supposedly local restaurant that turned out to be an undercover Chuck E. Cheese. For shame, Chuck E., for shame.(Jelisa Castrodale / Food and Wine)

GoogleStadia is a lonely place. Google s cloud streaming service feels like a virtual stadium that is still being built, and the crowds haven t arrived. (Tom Warren / The Verge)

Charli and Dixie D Amelio have leftTikTok sHype House. The sisters say they don t have any beef with the house members, though Charli and one of the founders did just break up. (Starr Bowenbank / Cosmopolitan)

LinkedInlaunched a virtual events tool to let people create and broadcast online gatherings on the platform. (Ingrid Lunden / TechCrunch)

Stuff to occupy you online during the quarantine.

Read the books these tech executives are into right now.

Try not to murder the person you live with over a petty gripe. Reading about other s petty gripes might help.

Mumbai, Sep 21 -- At a time when non-traditional competition is posing a challenge to traditional banking services, a new Capgemini report on Friday showed that globally just half of the customers are satisfied with their banking experiences
Nearly a third of customers (32.3 percent) are willing to consider big tech companies for financial products and services, showed the findings of the report titled "World Retail Banking Report 2018".


The report based on insights of customers and senior banking executives in over 40 countries, including India, charts the current perspectives and potential evolution of traditional banks amid the continued emergence of big technology and financial tech players in the financial services space.
"With fintechs, bigtechs, and other non-financial services firms finding their place in the market, retail banking today is all about the customer experience when interacting with their financial institution," said Anirban Bose, CEO of Capgemini's Financial Services Strategic Business Unit.
The open banking ecosystem, emerging technologies, and soaring customer expectations, are among the new challenges that retail banks across the world are now facing in addition to traditional challenges, the report said.
"As a new, open ecosystem -- comprised of customers, traditional banks, non-traditional firms, regulators, and developers -- takes shape, there is now a clear opportunity for banks to leverage digital transformation to retain customer relationships by re-inventing the customer journey and creating new revenue streams," Bose added.
The findings suggest that retail banks need to collaborate and personalise customer experience.
Satisfaction was notably higher among those customers who had been offered personalised digital experiences proactively (49.1 percent) than those who had not (39.5 percent), showed the research conducted in collaboration with Paris-headquartered global non-profit Efma.
The report also surveyed banking executives about the main causes of industry disruption. The most-cited factor was rising customer expectations, with nearly three out of four executives (70.8 per cent) stating that positive experiences in other sectors mean customers now expect more from their banking provider.
A majority of executives (58.3 per cent) also said that regulatory pressure was a cause of disruption, while 54.2 per cent identified the increasing demand for digital channels as a factor.
A significant majority of banking executives (70.8 per cent) think they can "generate non-traditional revenue" via collaboration with major technology companies.
"The retail banking industry is at an inflection point and needs to determine its role going forward in the open banking ecosystem. There is opportunity to innovate through collaboration as well as reinvention," said Vincent Bastid, Secretary General of Efma.
--IANS

urn:contentItem:5SY0-YNR1-DXH2-60DX-00000-00Half Year 2018 Reach PLC Earnings Call - Final2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:18ZLexisNexis073018a11684826.726Half Year 2018 Reach PLC Earnings Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* Simon Richard Fox

Reach plc - CEO & Executive Director

* Vijay Lakhman Vaghela

Reach plc - Group Finance Director, Group Company Secretary & Executive Director

Conference Call Participants

* Jonathan Mark Helliwell

Panmure Gordon & Co. plc, Research Division - Media Analyst

* Nicholas Michael Edward Dempsey

Barclays Bank PLC, Research Division - Research Analyst

* Thomas A Singlehurst

Citigroup Inc, Research Division - Director and Head of European Media Research

Presentation

SIMON RICHARD FOX, CEO & EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, REACH PLC: Well, good morning, everybody, and thank you very much indeed for joining us on a slightly damp Monday morning. As this is our first financial presentation as Reach plc, I thought I'd start by playing a short video to put some context behind the reason for our new name.

(presentation)

SIMON RICHARD FOX: There we go. So as usual, I'll take you through a few highlights before handing over to Vijay for a more detailed financial update on our first half performance. I will then return with a strategic and operational update.

So the biggest highlight of the half year was completing the acquisition of the Express & Star at the end of February and then receiving CMA and Ofcom clearance for the transaction on the 20th of June.

During the 4-month period of hold separate, the business was run by a highly competent interim management team that we were able to appoint post-acquisition.

Since receiving clearance, we've been working hard on our integration plans and remain confident in our ability to deliver GBP 20 million of annualized synergies by 2020. This deal transforms the scale of the group, both in print and in digital, and I'll talk about it in more detail later in the presentation.

Turning to the core business. It was a half year of contrasting fortunes. Nationally sold print advertising had a strong 6 months, with low single-figure percentage declines. However, regional advertising was disappointing and below our expectations. This slower performance in local advertising is reflected in the significant noncash impairment charge.

Growth in digital audience and revenue remains vital to our strategy. And although we saw audience growth, we, like most other news brands, were adversely affected by algorithm changes from Facebook and to a lesser extent, Google. And I'll come back to both of these points later. Despite this, we grew digital yields, with digital revenue growing faster than audience. The board has declared an interim dividend of 2.37p, representing an increase of 5.3% from the 2017 interim dividend. We remain confident in our clear strategy and anticipate trading for the year to be in line with expectations.

So let me now hand over to Vijay to cover the first half financial performance.

VIJAY LAKHMAN VAGHELA, GROUP FINANCE DIRECTOR, GROUP COMPANY SECRETARY & EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, REACH PLC: Thank you, Simon. Good morning, everyone. I'll start with the results of the acquired U.K. Publishing assets of Northern & Shell referred to as Express & Star in the presentation.

As you know, we completed the acquisition on 28th of February 2018, and the results are consolidated from the 1st of March. The results since completing the acquisition are shown on this slide. The business has had a strong performance since acquisition, with revenue of GBP 64.8 million and adjusted operating profit of GBP 10.8 million.

Publishing print revenue includes all circulation, advertising and other related revenue from our 4 newspapers and 3 magazines. Publishing digital includes all revenue from the 5 digital sites. Printing includes all third-party revenue generated by the Luton print plant acquired with the business. Key print contracts include a number of Metros outside London and CTAM.

Throughout the presentation, I will focus on adjusted results. Whilst there is no difference between statutory and adjusted revenue, I will refer to like-for-like revenue trends, as set out in this slide. I will start with our performance before moving on to the acquisition of Express & Star, adjusted items, cash flow, pensions, financing, and then conclude with an outlook.

Revenue increased by 10.6% to GBP 353.8 million, including revenue from Express & Star. On a like-for-like basis, revenue fell by 7.2%. Operating profit was up 6.2% to GBP 66.5 million, with EBITDA up 6.4% to GBP 77.6 million. Earnings per share increased by 1.7% to 18.2p per share. The increase reflects the benefit of the profits from Express & Star and is after the impact of issuing equity and raising debt to fund the acquisition. The business delivered a positive performance in the print market that has remained challenging, particularly in our regionals business.

You will have seen from our announcement this morning, we have had a statutory loss of GBP 107.3 million for the period due to a noncash impairment charge of GBP 150 million against the carrying value of the publishing rights and titles of our regionals business. I'll provide more detail on this in a moment.

I will now go through the performance by segment, starting with Publishing. Revenue increased by 11.5% to GBP 330.5 million. Excluding Express & Star, revenue fell by GBP 29.6 million, which includes the impact of handing back 2 Metros to DMGT and other portfolio changes. On a like-for-like basis, revenue fell by 7.4%. Operating profit increased by 5.5% to GBP 70.5 million, with operating margin falling by 1.2 percentage points to 21.3%, reflecting the lower margin from Express & Star and weaker performance from our regionals business due to a more challenging local print advertising market and slower-than-anticipated digital growth.

I will now talk you through the print and digital revenue trends, starting with print. Publishing print revenue increased by 10.6% on a like-for-like basis. This was a decline of 9.3%. Circulation revenue, which now represents 62% of print revenue, an increase of almost 5 percentage points from 2017, reflecting the impact of the acquisition of Express & Star, which has a higher percentage of the more resilient circulation revenue and lower levels of the more challenged print advertising. On a like-for-like basis, circulation revenue fell by 5.6%, with the benefit of cover price increases, which are helping to partially mitigate the impact of falling volumes. Circulation revenue trends have also been impacted by a change in sales in Spain, which are through a royalty agreement from July 2017. Excluding foreign copy sales, circulation revenue would have fallen by circa 5%.

Print advertising now represents 31% of print revenue, a fall of almost 5 percentage points from 2017, fell by 16.6% on a like-for-like basis. This is an improved performance from the 19.3% decline in 2017. The trends reflect continued high double-digit declines for locally sold advertising in the regional newspapers and advertising revenue in the paid-for magazines acquired with Express & Star. This has been partially mitigated by improved trends for national advertising across the entire portfolio of newspapers. On a like-for-like basis, display and other advertising revenue fell by 15.5%, and classified fell by 18.3%. Like-for-like Other print revenue fell by 5.4%, driven by declines in business enterprise and leaflets.

Publishing digital revenue grew by 16.9% to GBP 48.4 million. On a like-for-like basis, the growth was 6%, which is only marginally down on the 7% growth achieved in 2017. Display and transactional revenue grew by 11.5%, with classified revenue falling by 19.8%. The growth in digital and transactional revenue, which is predominantly linked to audience, now accounts for 86% of digital revenue, an increase of 4 percentage points from 2017. This reflects growth in page views on a like-for-like basis of 9.3%.

The growth in digital audience has been impacted by algorithm changes by Facebook and Google, and Simon will provide more insight into the steps we are taking to accelerate growth. We've also had strong growth in digital marketing services revenue in the period.

The decline in digital classified revenue, which is largely upsold from print, reflects the impact of falling print volumes. In particular, recruitment advertising, which represents 41% of classified revenue, was down 36.7%. The significant decline in recruitment has been partially mitigated by better performance from public notices and BMDs. Whilst we stride to maximize classified revenue, they now only represent 14% of total digital revenues.

I will now briefly cover our other businesses, starting with printing. Printing revenue increased by 3.6% to GBP 17.5 million. Printing now includes revenue of GBP 1.2 million from the Luton plant acquired with Express & Star. On a like-for-like basis, revenue fell by 0.6%, with falling volumes and newsprint supply for our customers, mostly offset by new contracts including the new Guardian print contract. Costs increased by GBP 9.2 million, and charges to the Publishing division increased by GBP 8.6 million, reflecting the costs associated with the Express & Star titles. Underlying costs continued to be tightly managed.

Our Specialist Digital businesses, comprising recruitment and email marketing services, experienced a marginal fall in revenue and increasing cost, resulting in operating profit falling by GBP 0.3 million. Net central loss improved by GBP 0.5 million to GBP 5 million. A revenue decline of GBP 0.7 million was driven by reduced rental income, as leases were terminated due to office closures and contraction of space, and we will see an increased level of decline in the second half.

Central costs fell by GBP 0.9 million to GBP 7 million, reflecting ongoing tight management of the cost base. Our share of income from associates increased by GBP 0.3 million, with our share of profits from the PA improving GBP 0.2 million, and we've also achieved GBP 0.1 million share of profits from Brand Events, which we invested in during 2016.

I will now go through group costs.

Group costs increased by GBP 30.2 million to GBP 288.1 million. Excluding Express & Star, costs fell by GBP 23.8 million, with GBP 9 million of structural cost savings. We are now targeting structural cost savings for the full year of GBP 18 million, GBP 3 million ahead of our original target. Cost savings have been delivered across all cost categories. In addition to structural cost savings, we have commenced the integration of Express & Star, and at this stage, we anticipate synergy savings of GBP 2 million in the second half of the year. We will also continue to tightly manage the portfolio of newspaper titles and close titles which move into loss and where there are no initiatives that would move these titles into profitability.

The continued drive for efficiencies will help offset the impact of a further increase in newsprint prices in the second half. During the period, we incurred GBP 7.9 million of restructuring costs in the delivery of the cost-reduction measures, and we expect cost of circa GBP 20 million in delivery of GBP 18 million of structural cost savings and GBP 2 million of synergy savings in 2018. The restructuring costs for the year include an element of cost associated with the delivery of synergy savings in 2019.

I will now talk you through the consideration paid in payable for the acquisition of Express & Star. Total equity value for the acquisition is GBP 121.7 million, with cash consideration of GBP 101.7 million and GBP 20 million settled through the issue of new shares in Reach plc. The total cash consideration of GBP 101.7 million will be paid in 5 tranches: initial cash consideration of GBP 42.7 million paid on completion; 4 tranches of GBP 11.9 million, GBP 16 million, GBP 17.1 million and GBP 7 million to be paid on the second, third, fourth and fifth anniversaries of completion respectively. These total GBP 59 million. This total cash consideration of GBP 101.7 million excludes a net working capital adjustment of GBP 0.1 million.

In addition to equity consideration, the group has made an initial payment to the Express & Star pension scheme of GBP 41.2 million and entered into a new recovery plan with payments of GBP 29.2 million over the next 10 years. The cash consideration, initial payments of the pension schemes and transaction costs have been funded by drawing GBP 70 million on a new GBP 75 million, 4-year acquisition term loan with the balance drawn on our existing GBP 91.7 million RCF and cash balances. A further GBP 5 million will be payable on completion of the acquisition of the assets in Republic of Ireland, which is conditional upon obtaining regulatory clearance. The remaining GBP 5 million undrawn on the acquisition facility will be drawn for this purpose.

We incurred transaction costs of GBP 8.5 million on the acquisition, with GBP 6.3 million in the period and GBP 2.2 million during 2017.

The reconciling items between statutory and adjusted operating profit totaled GBP 173.8 million. The most significant item in the period is the GBP 150 million impairment of the carrying value of publishing rights and titles for the regionals business. The trading environment for local advertising in our regionals business has been more challenging in the first half than expected, with high double-digit declines in print advertising and reduced levels of growth in digital display and transactional revenue. This has contributed to a reduction in future projections for revenue and cash flows in the model used for assessing the value of the regionals' publishing rights and titles. Whilst this noncash charge reflects the impact of the more challenging local advertising environment, it does not fully account for, as required by accounting standards, the benefit of the scale of our digital audiences and opportunities to drive revenue and profit in the longer term. The charge relates to the former Trinity Mirror and Local World regional businesses and is not specific to any acquisition. Other than the impairment charge, the most significant items are restructuring, transaction costs for the acquisition of Express & Star and an increase in the provision for historical legal issues of GBP 7.5 million. I have already covered the first 2 of these.

We increased the provision for historical legal issues as the costs of settling claims, in particular the claimants' legal costs, are higher than expected. The remaining provision at the period-end is GBP 11.6 million. This process is taking longer than previously anticipated due to the complex and lengthy legal process with increased legal costs, and creates ongoing uncertainty. Whilst the level of uncertainty prevails, the board remains confident that this is manageable and does not undermine the delivery of our strategy.

In addition to the acquisition transaction cost to date, we expect some cost in the second half as we move to obtain regulatory clearance on the GBP 5 million acquisition of the assets in the Republic of Ireland.

We continue to generate strong cash flows during the year, with net cash inflow of GBP 28.6 million before distribution to shareholders. Key items of note in the period are: increasing capital expenditure of GBP 2.6 million to GBP 7 million as we migrated part of our IT infrastructure to the cloud, continued the integration of our former Local World businesses on the Reach Publishing platform and the rollout of new finance systems. We anticipate capital expenditure of GBP 15 million for the full year, including capital expenditure relating to Express & Star. We made contributions to defined benefit pension schemes of GBP 24.4 million excluding the GBP 41.2 million initial payment -- an increase of GBP 6.3 million, reflecting the new recovery plans and contributions to the Express & Star pension schemes. And there was GBP 90.1 million of cash outflows for the acquisition of Express & Star, which includes the cash payments for equity, working capital, initial pension payment and transaction costs.

Before going through financing, I will provide some further detail on pensions. The IAS 19 pension deficit fell by GBP 80.6 million to GBP 297 million. On a post-tax basis, the deficit fell by GBP 69.1 million to GBP 242.3 million. The GBP 297 million deficit is net of an accounting surplus of GBP 5.9 million on the Express & Star pension schemes. Excluding Express & Star, the pension schemes deficit fell by GBP 74.7 million. The fall in the deficit reflects strong asset returns, company contributions and a favorable movement in the discount rate and inflation assumptions, which resulted in the real discount rate improving by 0.2 percentage points from a negative 6 -- 0.65% to a negative 0.45%. Included in the Express & Star schemes, approximately 13% of scheme liabilities are hedged through insurance contracts, which provide protection against volatility in the financial markets. The liabilities are very sensitive to movements in the discount rate. A 50 basis points increase in the discount rate with all assumptions remaining -- all other assumptions remaining the same would result in liabilities falling by GBP 202 million and the deficit falling by GBP 183 million.

Although there are deficits in our schemes, there are no liquidity issues, and the schemes continue to meet the majority of the benefit payments through investment income and company contributions.

Contributions for the second half will be GBP 24.5 million, with contributions for the next 2 years of GBP 48.9 million per annum. The next actuarial valuations for all 6 schemes will be December 2019, and we anticipate these to be completed by the end of 2020, ahead of the March 2021 statutory deadline.

The continued robust cash flows of the business ensured net debt only increased by GBP 72 million to GBP 81 million, after expending GBP 90.1 million in relation to the acquisition of Express & Star. The group has 2 financing facilities: the GBP 91.7 million amortizing revolving credit facility and that GBP 75 million acquisition term loan, both of which are committed until December 2021. On 27th of July 2018, the group prepaid the GBP 10 million repayment due in December '18 under the acquisition term loan. The amortization of the RCF and term loan is shown in this slide, reflecting the early repayment.

Leverage is maintained below 1x full year adjusted EBITDA, and the group had GBP 61.7 million undrawn facilities at the period-end. This illustrates the financial flexibility the group maintains.

I will now conclude with current trading and an outlook for 2018. In July, like-for-like revenue is expected to fall by 7%. Although the trading environment for print is expected to remain difficult, the board anticipates trading for the year to be in line with market expectations, with a further increase in newsprint pricing in the second half of the year to be mitigated by further cost reductions and synergies from the acquisition of Express & Star.

Thank you, all. I'll now pass you back to Simon.

SIMON RICHARD FOX: Thank you very much, Vijay. I'm going to briefly cover some operational highlights from the first half of the year. I'll remind you of our strategy, and then share a little more detail with you on our plans for the integration of the Express & Star titles. I'll then briefly cover the strategic importance to the group of our regional digital business.

Print circulation revenue is the largest single revenue component of the group, representing 62% of print revenue and 50% of total group revenue. The line in black on this graph shows the monthly ABC performance of the Daily Mirror, which I know some of you follow, whilst the orange line shows our paid-for circulation.

Whilst circulation trends remain negative, the paid-for performance of the Daily Mirror over the first 6 months of the year did improve marginally, despite an annual cover price rise of 5p on the 12th of March.

Our ABC performance has improved as we reach the anniversary of the cessation of free airport copies in May and the change to our Spanish supply arrangements in July.

We saw a marked improvement in national print advertising in the first half of the year compared to 2017, with mid-single-figure percentage declines. This was a result both of a stronger national print advertising market and also an improved market share performance, both due to the benefit of the World Cup and also to a strong performance from the supermarket and from our own success selling creative solutions to advertisers like Halfords, McDonald's and Smart Energy meters.

Our digital audience grew in the first half, but more slowly than last year. As you will have seen and heard from other news organizations, this was largely due to the algorithm change from Facebook in January.

Over the first half, we've put in place a number of measures to drive digital traffic. These include: product improvements to increase our search traffic, a focus on alternative traffic sources such as Twitter and Instagram, and increased efforts to drive traffic directly to our sites and app. In addition, the rebranding of our regional site to the live brand, which I'll come back to in a moment, and the reorganization of regional newsrooms, were already starting to have a positive impact on traffic trends.

Pleasingly, we've been able to grow our digital yields, and as such, our digital display and transactional revenue has grown ahead of growth in page views.

Our strategic objective remains to deliver sustainable growth in revenue, profit and cash flow. We've refreshed our strategic pillars following the Express & Star acquisition to optimize, grow and commercialize.

In respect of optimize, our strategy is to continue to enhance our print brands and to improve their longevity through quality journalism and content delivered as efficiently as possible. Print will, however, not get us to growth, and growing our digital audience and revenue remains our highest priority. We will therefore use the best technology, data and content from across all of our brands to continue growing our digital reach, whilst at the same time improving our revenue performance and seeking out new opportunities and revenue streams to commercialize this growing digital audience.

Whilst the priority for the year ahead is to deliver the benefits from our recent acquisition, we will consider M&A opportunities which accelerate our strategy and where the financial case meets our requirements.

Let me now turn to the Express & Star acquisition and start by reminding you of the scale that we now have in both print and digital. Scale matters not only because it will enable us to produce better content at lower cost, but also because it presents a number of revenue opportunities.

Let me touch on the revenue opportunity. Advertising agencies and clients are increasingly looking to simplify their purchase decisions and deal with a partner that has both the scale and breadth of audience. Our print brands span average ages from 39 to 66. We can reach both male and female audiences as well as the full sociodemographic range. This will make us a first choice partner for advertising agencies. And by November, we will merge 2 currently separate standalone advertising sales teams into 1 best-in-class sales operation. We will ensure that we are easy to buy from and able to offer advertisers the very best in creative media solutions.

With our significant digital scale, we will also be able to invest in the best digital platforms to both optimize the reader experience and revenue. Our scale enables us to build strong direct relationships with the big tech partners and platforms.

The combination of 2 national news businesses will enable us to produce better content at lower cost. We're in the process of creating new organizational structures and workflows based on the principle of creating the content once, wherever possible, and thus avoiding unnecessary duplication. We'll be creating new content hubs that will serve all our national brands. These will include breaking news and features such as gardening, motoring, technology and showbiz. A sports hub will enable us to cover a wider breadth of football matches and other sports. We'll be bringing the Scottish Daily Express and Scottish Star into the offices of the Daily Record so that they can benefit from the extensive Scottish content that we have in the group. We will look to reduce the number of picture desks that currently operate across the businesses, and we'll see what opportunities exist for sharing supplements across our titles. We will streamline and simplify the production process wherever possible. We will do all this whilst ensuring we maintain the editorial independence and integrity of each title, in particular respecting the different political stances taken by the Daily Mirror and Daily Express.

This slide is a real life example taken from last week. The Mirror's David Anderson was in Charlotte in the United States for Liverpool's preseason tour and filed copy about Liverpool's goalkeeping and defensive frailties. One reporter, one story, but treated and presented in different ways to preserve the brand identity and the style of each paper, but using one source of content, just one of many examples of cost-effectiveness without sacrificing quality and professionalism.

The acquisition brings a new printing plant into our network. Luton is the most modern plant in the country with 22 high-speed print units. Luton, like the rest of our plants, is currently fully utilized, both for printing Express & Star titles but also third-party customers. There are, however, immediate synergies which we can deliver by moving certain print runs across our network to minimize distribution costs. In the longer term, there may be opportunities to rationalize the network, thereby saving more significant costs.

Let me now turn to our regionals business. And although it's been a tough 6 months, with local advertising in particular performing below our expectations, our regional digital business remains of key strategic importance. Over the past 12 months, we've rebranded all of our regional digital sites except for the Liverpool Echo and Manchester Evening News to the live brand. We've done this for a number of reasons. Firstly, to clearly indicate to our readers that our digital sites are not simply a copy of the newspaper online. In fact, the content in digital and print is becoming increasingly different, and rightly so. Our digital readers are generally not our print readers. There are more of them, for a start, and they tend to be younger and more likely to be based or working in the city center. Equally, our digital advertisers are increasingly different to our print advertisers. The graph on this slide, which asks readers which characteristic they associate with the name Birmingham Live compared to the previous name of Birmingham Mail, illustrates that the Live brand scores more positively on almost every metric. The Live brand also works well in cities where we've never had a print presence. You may recall we started this in Dublin and Belfast. We launched Leeds Live in November 2017, and Edinburgh Live is coming soon.

As these 2 graphs show, we've established a strong track record of launching live sites in new locations and quickly scaling them up to become a significant part of the city they serve. Belfast Live is now achieving 7 million page views each month, and Leeds Live achieved 1.7 million page views in the month of June, after just 7 months of operation.

You've seen this graph before, and it indicates the enormous relevance our digital brands have in the cities they serve, with our larger brands reaching around 50% of the local population over the course of a week.

In addition to launching in new cities, we continue to look for new content areas or other opportunities where we can use our technology and expertise to grow new audiences. football.london is a great example of this. In just 18 months, it's become our sixth largest regional site, achieving 12.7 million page views in June. We're also seeing good growth from our hyperlocal site, InYourArea, which is a postcode-based content aggregation product, which employs no dedicated journalists.

We're particularly interested in finding new revenue opportunities beyond traditional advertising. We're experimenting with a wide range of new revenue sources on InYourArea such as trade and property listings. And we also continue to develop transactional revenue streams such as from betting, ticketing and retail.

And outside of digital, our joint venture events business, Brand Events, has had a strong summer season with our successful Pub in the Park concept having scaled up to 4 events this year with plans for 6 to 8 events in 2019. We've also launched a third Handmade Fair.

So in summary, it's been a positive financial performance across the first half of the year in a difficult trading environment for the industry, in particular the regionals. And we anticipate trading for the year to be in line with expectations.

The Express & Star acquisition is a transformational moment for the group, which changes our scale in both print and digital and gives us the opportunity to drive significant cost and revenue synergies. We were pleased to gain competition clearance a few weeks ago, and our integration program is up and running. We have a clear strategy to ensure we crystallize the benefits of this scale to drive profitable growth.

Thank you for your attention, and Vijay and I would be very happy to take any question.

Questions and Answers

NICHOLAS MICHAEL EDWARD DEMPSEY, RESEARCH ANALYST, BARCLAYS BANK PLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Nick Dempsey from Barclays. I've got 3, please. First of all, on digital, how do you think about the issue around the Facebook algorithm change? So are we looking at this as -- in early 2019, you anniversary against that and you return to the kind of growth that you would've hoped to have done before because that's behind you? Or are we saying that what they're doing, and Google and other people is permanently reducing your potential to grow in the kind of digital display advertising? Second question, a bit of a follow-on. I mean, Facebook, on the one hand, they're impacting your traffic. On the other hand, they've been taking aggressive share away from print media for 7, 8 years, causing the regulator to have to look at the situation where they can, on the one hand, affect your business; and on the other, benefit from it? And third question, just on the pension. Are we saying the earliest that we could see a reduction in the cash top-ups is 2022 if the -- we've got a March 2021 deadline for the completion of the next actuarial review?

SIMON RICHARD FOX: I'll take the first 2. In terms of Facebook, Facebook made this fundamental change to their News Feed in January, where professional news was reduced overall by 20%. So on average, previously, 5% of people's feeds had professionally produced news in it and that was consciously reduced by them to 4%. Whilst you can never necessarily believe everything, I was at a meeting just last week and they are assuring the news industry that, that is done. So we would expect to see -- we would expect to see an anniversary effect. In addition, they are now starting to prioritize certain publishers based on 3 upweight factors. One of those is local, which, of course, should benefit us; at the second is trusted, which should also benefit us; and the third is informative. So I think initially, they took a pretty aggressive approach to all news providers. I would expect to see us starting to benefit as the dial is turned slightly in our favor. What they're fighting is essentially fake news on the platform. And I think in order to address fake news, to some degree, they've had to address all news. And as they get more sophisticated, I think they will be able to differentiate between the two. The other thing though is we've taken a conscious decision to be increasingly less reliant on Facebook as a source for news. We still believe it should be important. That is where people spend their time, and if people are spending their time there, we want our content to be there but we don't want to become overly reliant, and hence, our clear strategy to sort of diversify traffic sources. On regulation, I wouldn't hold my breath greatly. There are a number of reviews ongoing, including the Cairncross Review into the sustainability of the press. I think the government and the DCMS just reported yesterday on their fake news inquiry. So the government is definitely concerned about the impact on news from the platforms, but I wouldn't necessarily hold my breath and expect the cavalry to come charging over the hill. I think we have to assume that nothing much will change. And on pensions?

VIJAY LAKHMAN VAGHELA: Yes. So the valuation date is December '19, so we would expect to complete that by the end of 2020. So we would expect an impact on contributions from '21, not '22.

SIMON RICHARD FOX: I'll do the first one, and you do the second one. SIMON RICHARD FOX: Not a flash in the pan, not just due to the summer barbecue, although that, of course, helps. Obviously, we came to a good conclusion and a relatively swift conclusion so I think they do understand the pressures that the industry is under. And I think that they would be more open, particularly perhaps to collaboration and consolidation. They'll need to look at each -- the merits of each particular deal. But I think they do recognize that the industry needs perhaps to work more closely together. One of the things that is going on at the moment is a digital collaboration of news brands, and I think they'd be completely open to those sorts of combined sales houses, for example, or not all -- combined sales approach, I should say. I think you also...

JONATHAN MARK HELLIWELL: Just about the, is the regional, does it matter -- do they pick those 2 markets and they put them together?

SIMON RICHARD FOX: Yes, they do look at them as 2 markets, absolutely, very much so. And that's -- I think they would still prefer a regional consolidation. They would look at sort of postcode level or market-by-market level.

Check whether there are any questions on the phone.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) There are no questions over the audio at this time.

SIMON RICHARD FOX: Very good. Thank you all very much, indeed. I think we're done.
